titleStmt.title: Elastic and plastic properties of as-cast equimolar TiHfZrTaNb high-entropy alloy

analytic.title: Elastic and plastic properties of as-cast equimolar TiHfZrTaNb high-entropy alloy

biblStruct.note: Received date: 16 October 2015 Revised date: 9 December 2015 Accepted date: 11 December 2015

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

keywords.term: Materials Science & Engineering A High entropy alloy

div.p: Elastic properties of as-cast TiHfZrTaNb high entropy alloy were investigated by ultrasound measurements, yielding G = C 44 = 28 GPa and C 11 = 172 GPa effective isotropic elastic constants, allowing computation of the Young's modulus E, the bulk modulus B and Poisson ratio Q of about 78.5 GPa, 134.6 GPa and 0.402, respectively. A Pugh ratio G/B as lower as 0.208 and high positive Cauchy pressure (C 12 -C 44 ) = 80 GPa were calculated, suggesting a ductile behavior. Tensile tests were carried out on specimens taken along the ingot diameter to address micro-segregations effect on the macroscopic behavior. More specifically, micro-segregations were addressed at a smaller scale via nanohardness measurements. Given the observed low deviations from both tensile and nanoindentation experiments, micro-segregations influence was concluded to be negligible. The necking and fracture surface investigations revealed multiples slip bands, grains boundary distortions, mixture of shallow and profound 2 dimples of varying sizes, all of which characterize a high tensile ductility behavior, in line with elasticity measurements prediction. Post-mortem EBSD investigations revealed lattice distortions mainly at grain boundaries vicinity as a consequence of dislocations accumulation.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Optimizing the composition of alloying elements for a given microstructure has been the conventional way to enhance material properties such as strength, toughness, corrosion resistance or ductility. In this framework the concept of high entropy alloy has been proposed [1,2]. Indeed, HEAs are composed of equiatomic or nearly equiatomic metallic elements, wherein the mixing entropy is maximized, leading to the extended solid solubility and formation of a single or a double-phase structure [3]. Such solid solutions with multi-principal elements have been found to be kinetically stable due to the sluggish diffusion of atoms [2], preventing intermetallic compounds from precipitating. For high temperature applications, the work of Senkov and his group paved the road for the development of HEAs based on the refractory elements (Ti, Zr, Hf, V, Nb, Ta, Cr, Mo and W) [4][5][6][7][8][9][10]. For instance, in a recent study, Fazakas et al [11] successfully prepared news refractory HEAs consisting of the elements of 4 th and 5 th as well as 4 th Senkov et al [7] these alloys showed superior mechanical properties in compression at high temperature compared to conventional high temperature alloys. In a recent report Wu et al. [12] demonstrated first room temperature tensile behavior of Hf 25 Nb 25 Ti 25 Zr 25 HEA. The homogenized alloy exhibited yield strength of about 879 MPa that was accompanied by a room temperature ductility of about 15%. Zou et al. [13] studied the size dependent plasticity in Nb 25 Mo 25 Ta 25 W 25 alloy. They reported extraordinarily high strength levels of about 4-4.5 GPa for HEA pillars (2 Pm-200nm), 3-3.5 times higher than the bulk counterpart. More recently, Tsai and Yeh proposed a critical review on HEAs [14]. In the same line, a compilation of room temperature mechanical properties of some HEAs so far studied in the literature have been presented by Wu et al. [15].
From the above-mentioned literature, it turns out that refractory HEAs exhibit high specific yield strengths, while their plastic strains are in the range 5-50% in compression loading conditions.
Experimental measurements of the elastic properties of this family of alloys are scarce.

Most of the available literature data stem from theoretical calculations. For example, in their theoretical pioneering work Tian et al. [16] described the bulk properties of refractory HEAs using first-principles theory. They showed that in contrast to the Mofree alloy, the Mo-containing alloys seem to be almost isotropic. The Young's modulus changes between 136.0 and 149.2 GPa for TiZrVNbMo, and between 139.9 and 144.3 GPa for TiZrNbMo. Similarly, the shear modulus varies a little between 50.9 and 54.5

GPa for TiZrVNbMo, and between 52.6 and 53.8 GPa for TiZrNbMo. Interestingly, in the work of Fazakas et al [11], additional theoretical calculations performed by the Exact Muffin-Tin Orbitals method (EMTO) with local density approximation (LDA) to the exchange correlation energy functional in density functional theory (DFT) within the coherent potential approximation (CPA) were provided for some disordered alloys.

div.head: Sample processing:
div.p: Arc melting and induction routes under inert atmosphere were used to process the refractory high-entropy alloy having the equi-atomic Ti 20 Zr 20 Hf 20 Nb 20 Ta 20 composition.

In this process, two master alloys, Nb-Ta and Ti-Zr-Hf, were first arc-melted under argon on a water-cooled copper plate from high purity metals (exceeding 99.9% purity) in the form of slugs and wires. In a subsequent step, each alloy was re-melted twice to improve homogeneity and then mixed together. A titanium getter was used prior each arc-melting fusion in order to capture the residual oxygen in the chamber. Homogeneity in the alloy was obtained by high frequency induction melting in a sectorized cooled copper crucible under helium atmosphere. At the end, the homogenized refractory alloy was obtained by arc melting in the form of an ingot with 60 mm in length and approximately 10 mm in diameter.

div.head: Deformation and fracture surface analysis
div.p: Electron Back-Scattering Diffraction (EBSD) technique and Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) observations were carried out to investigate the as-cast microstructure and the deformation and failure characteristics. Samples for EBSD investigations and chemical analysis (electron probe micro analysis EPMA and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy EDS) were prepared by mechanical grinding using 1200 to 4000 grit SiC papers followed by a final polishing step using a 20 nm alumina oxide particle suspension (OPS) from Struers™. EPMA analysis was performed on a Cameca SX100 micro-analyser operating at 15 keV, EDS analysis and SE images acquired on a Zeiss Merlin SEM and a Zeiss Supra 40VP FEG SEM was used for EBSD investigations. For the latter and due to the wide grain size distribution in the as-cast material, a step size between the neighboring measurement positions of 1 Pm was used.
For statistical purpose, all the scans were performed on an area greater than 1 mm x 1 mm.

The fractions of low angle grain boundaries (LAGBs) and high angle grain boundaries (HAGBs), the grain boundary (GB) and the inverse pole figure (IPF) maps were extracted from the EBSD scans using OIM software version 5 from TexSem Laboratories (TSL). In addition, the Kernel Average Misorientation (KAM) function was used to determine local values of intragranular lattice rotation. KAM is numerically defined as the average of misorientation between the pixel of interest and all specified nearest neighbor pixels. For a given point, the average misorientation with all neighbors is calculated with the provision that misorientations exceeding some tolerance value are excluded from averaging. For the present calculation, a maximum misorientation angle of 5° (upper limit for KAM computation) was selected which corresponds to the lattice distortion of 1 °/μm at the applied kernel diameter of 10 μm.

div.head: Room temperature tensile tests
div.p: Quasi-static tensile tests were carried out by means of a 5 kN Deben Micro-test tensile/compressive testing machine (Deben UK Ltd). The tests were performed at RT at a strain rate of 5u10 -3 s -1 . The samples were electro-discharge machined (EDM) from the as-cast ingot as shown in Fig. 1 to address the possible influence of the microstructure heterogeneity that was presented in a previous work [17].

div.head: Nanoindentation measurements
div.p: The studied sample was removed from the top of the ingot, i.e. where the cooling is the slowest and thus where the dendritic microstructure is the more pronounced. This corresponds to sample 1 or 2 for tensile tests (Fig. 1). The same polishing procedure as for EBSD characterization (2.2) was performed. Beforehand the area of interest was marked by three Vickers micro-indents in order to be able to find this area both for SEM-EDS characterization and for nanoindentation. A nanoindenter equipped with a Berkovich tip was used both for Scanning Probe Microscopy which provides 3D image of the surface topography and for nanoindentation tests. An arithmetic roughness of 1.1 nm and a tilt of the surface of 0.35° was measured on a 10 × 10 µm² SPM image. Thus indents with a maximum depth of 40 nm or more, which corresponds for this material to a maximum applied load of 300 µN, are not influenced by the surface quality of the sample [18]. The width of such an indent is 280 nm. To avoid any interference with the indentation deformation field, the distance between two indents was set to 1 µm, i.e. larger than three times the width of the indent.
For each indentation, the maximum applied load was 300 µN, the loading and unloading rates were 1 mN.s -1 and the maximum load was maintained during 2 s.
Hardness was determined by using the Oliver and Phar model [19].

div.head: Ultrasound measurements
div.p: Given the random grains orientation as revealed by EBSD investigations, the samples were considered having in average an effective isotropic elastic symmetry if the probed volume by each technique is big enough to contain a large number of grains. Therefore, in the present study, only two independent elastic constants C 11 and C 44 have to be determined. To this end, the longitudinal (V L ) and the transversal (V T ) sound velocity were measured by two acoustic complementary techniques. First, the pulse-echo technique was employed to measure V L from time of flight of echoes that are traveling forth and back along the higher length (19.21 ± 0.01 mm) of the cylindrical shaped sample with 8.7 ± 0.01 mm in diameter and opposite parallel faces. The travel time of ultrasonic waves propagating through the sample with a 10 MHz frequency was measured using a Sofranel D20 ultrasound device with a measuring time accuracy of 0.5 ns. The accuracy for the acoustic velocity is about 0.1%. Brillouin scattering of light by bulk and surface acoustic waves in solids is governed by two mechanisms. First, it can exist a coupling between the incident light and acoustic excitations according to well-defined selection rules involving the bulk elasto-optic constants of the material [20]. Secondly, scattering can arise from the diffraction of the incident beam on the illuminated surface of the sample that suffers dynamical corrugations initiated by the acoustic waves with a vertical displacement component [21,22]. This last mechanism, the so-called ripple-mechanism, is usually predominant in opaque media and concerns more specifically the surface excitations whereas the elastooptic mechanism is responsible for the scattering by bulk acoustic phonons in transparent compounds, leading to the direct determination of the elastic constants.

In very opaque materials like good metals, the low penetration depth of light leads to Brillouin spectra exhibiting only surface characteristic features via the ripplemechanism. For ripple-scattering, only the wave-vector component k parallel to the surface of the sample is conserved and the relevant wave-vector of the surface modes in a backscattering arrangement becomes k || = 2k i sin (T where k i is imposed by the incident wavelength O i = 532 nm of the laser (k i = 2S/O i ) and T is the angle between the incident beam and the normal to the surface which can be experimentally chosen (see Fig. 2). The Rayleigh surface wave is confined to a depth of 1-2 acoustic wavelengths / a = O i /(2 sin (T below the free surface, typically below 1 Pm.

In the case of semi-infinite solid like our HEA sample, the analysis of the Brillouin spectra requires a Green function approach of the equation of motion of elasticity which allows the determination of the spectral density of the perpendicular atomic displacement u z of the free surface (at z = 0) [21,22]. The ripple-scattered intensity at the frequency Z and wave-vector k || is proportional to <u 2 z (0)> k||, Z . Considering an isotropic medium characterized by the two bulk waves velocities V L and V T , the calculation of <u 2 z (0)> k||, Z exhibits a pole at Z R corresponding to the Rayleigh surface wave with velocity V R = Z R /k || < V T ; at higher frequencies, it presents a continuum between Z T = k || V T (the transverse threshold TT) and Z L = k || V L (the longitudinal threshold LT). In this simple isotropic case, fitting the Brillouin spectra using this spectral density allows to determine the longitudinal V L and transverse V T bulk velocities from typical surface excitations [23]. Due to limited signal other noise ratio,

V L value was kept to the previous derived sonar technique value. A single-mode solid laser operating at 532 nm illuminates the sample with a spot light of diameter 50-100 Pm and the scattered light is analyzed using a six-pass tandem Fabry-Perot interferometer [24]. Room temperature experiments were performed at various angles of incidence (45-65°) and different locations on the surface of the sample.

div.head: 3.1.As processed Microstructure
div.p: The initial microstructure of the as-cast material is shown in Fig. 3 and was presented in previous works [25,26]. Figure 3a shows an EBSD IPF map. It shows a wide size distribution of randomly oriented grains (see top left insert), which was also confirmed by the overall crystallographic texture measurements (pole figures) presented in Fig. 3b (RD and TD labels have no special meaning here). However, a maximum intensity level of about 16 is noted which is most probably related to the presence of very large grains (~ 600 microns) within the distribution of grain size. Unindexed areas in some grains seen in Fig. 3b (see the left side of the image) are related to micro-segregation in the interdendritic zones [17].

div.head: Sound waves measurements and elastic constants
div.p: First, the pulse-echo technique was employed to measure V L from time of flight of echoes that are traveling forth and back along the higher length (19.21 ± 0.01 mm) of the cylindrical shaped sample with 8.7 mm ± 0.01 mm in diameter and opposite parallel polished faces. Two echoes were observed from which V L was estimated to be 4166 ± 4 m/s. Due to the small lateral size available for the sample, shear sound velocity was not possible with an available shear wave transducer working at oblique incidence.

Second, we used the Brillouin light scattering technique that enabled us to measure the Rayleigh surface wave velocity V R as the raw experimental output data from at least tree experiments with angle of incidence of light 45°, 55° and 65°, and different locations on the free surface, but in blind manner as no optical imaging of the surface was available.

All measurements for one angle of incidence provided close results indicating that isotropic symmetry is a reasonable assumption in this case. Unfortunately, without surface imaging, we cannot conclude if we probed a single large grain or an assembly of small grains.

A typical anti-Stokes (Z > 0) part of a spectrum obtained at T = 65° (i.e. k || = 2. Our experimental G value is ~25% below the VRH average calculated by Fazakas et al [11] (38 ± 7 GPa) while C 11 is only ~10% lower than the calculated VRH value (187 ± 9 GPa). One should notice that the Reuss average with the lower bound value provided the closest agreement, potentially indicating an isostress situation for all grains.
From these two elastic constants, Young's modulus E, bulk modulus B and Poisson ratio Q can be calculated using the following equations for an isotropic material:

We found E = 78.5 GPa, B = 134.6 GPa and Q = 0.402. Our experimental E value is ~20% below the VRH average calculated by Fazakas et al [11] (104 ± 17 GPa) while B is in very good agreement (136.3 GPa) and Q 10% higher than the calculated RVH value (0.373 ± 0.02). One should again notice that the Reuss average with the lower bound value (higher bound value for Q) provided the closest agreement, potentially indicating an isostress situation for all grains.

The ratio G/E~0.360 is slightly lower than 3/8 experimentally found for polycrystalline metallic materials [27]. It is also lower than 0.390 previously theoretically estimated for fcc polycrystalline metals but very close to 0.367 found for bcc metals [28] providing us with a good confidence in our results. Pugh initially proposed a relationship based on the G/B ratio for polycrystalline metals and introduced a critical ratio (G/B) crit allowing to define a scale going from ductile (at low G/B values) to brittle (at higher G/B values) [29]. This critical ratio depends on the crystalline structure of the material considered.

This criterion has been later developed and quantified by others [30,31]. For bcc polycrystalline metals, the brittle to ductile transition, though not so well defined, is observed for an average value (G/B) crit a 0.55. The G/B ratio being related to Poisson ratio, this limit can be equivalently thought of as a critical Poisson ratio. Later, Pettifor introduced a criterion linking the brittle-to-ductile transition in polycrystalline cubic materials to the Cauchy pressure (C 12 -C 44 ), a parameter related to the angular character of bonds [32]. Based on his findings, positive Cauchy pressures correspond to a metallic character and to a ductile behavior of the material, while negative values involve a strong angular character of bonds, as observed in covalent bonding, and a brittle behavior. The ratio G/B reaches a value as lower as 0.208 and a high positive Cauchy pressure (C 12 -C 44 ) = 80 GPa that should result to a high ductility behavior. It is indeed confirmed by the tensile tests (see section 3.4). One should notice that such high value of Cauchy pressure is also observed in metallic glasses [33] but with higher value of G/B.

div.head: Investigation by tensile tests
div.p: Figure 5a shows the true stress versus plastic strain plots as a function of sample position along the diameter of the ingot as described in Fig. 1 (the plot for sample 1 is not shown here because of early failure most probably related to EDM). It is noticed that each curve in Fig. 5a reflects the evolution of the true stress before strain localization and damage (which may occur due to the influence of defects in the as-cast microstructure, such as porosity…). The general trends are as follows:

-Sample 2 taken from the area having the higher level of chemical micro-segregation has a yield stress of ~810 MPa and a low positive strain hardening, the true stress reachinges a peak stress of a890 MPa;

-Samples 3 (low level of chemical micro-segregation), 4 and 5 (both in the chemically homogeneous zone) show similar trends as the three curves overlap almost perfectly up to about a plastic strain of a4%. The corresponding peak stresses are in the range 855 -865 MPa. The Lower value corresponds to sample 5.

In order to more closely analyze the mechanical characteristics, Fig. 5b, displays a blowup of Fig. 5a that was limited to 0.002 plastic strain offset. In this range of plastic strains, contrariwise to the above description, there is a perfect overlapping of the behaviors of samples 4 and 5. Overall, it is assumed that there is no direct correlation between the sample position along the diameter of the ingot and the macroscopic mechanical properties, the deviation in the flow stress being about ± 15MPa. It is thus suggested that the envelope bounded by the green curve and the red curves in Fig. 5b characterizes the macroscopic behavior: the yield stress is in the range 790-805 MPa and the yield stress at 0.002 offset strain is in the range 820-835 MPa. On average, these results are in the range of values previously reported [23] and [24] after compression loadings on this alloy for the same metallurgical state.

div.head: Mechanical behavior via nano-indentation testing
div.p: Given the tensile test results on specimen taken from different part of the as-cast ingot, which correspond to different level of micro-segregation, it is very likely that microsegregations do not influence the mechanical properties. In order to confirm this result, nanoindentation tests were performed on a dendritic zone to detect, on the microscopic scale, a possible variation in hardness between dendrites and interdendritic zones. An EPMA mapping of the sample was previously done to verify the presence of dendrites and is given in Figure 6a. They are very pronounced and about 20 µm wide. 416 indents were performed covering an area of 25 x 15 µm² and were spaced 1 µm one from another. Those dimensions were chosen so as to independently measure the hardness of dendrites and interdendritic zones by several indents. A Zr EDS mapping of the indented zone (subzone of Figure 6a) is given in Figure 6b, and Figure 6c shows the exact same zone with the indents. As can be seen from comparison of these two images, the indentation map overlaps indeed with a microsegregation. The average of the 416 hardness measurements is 4.9 ± 0.2 GPa. The standard deviation is inferior than 10%, so the variations are within the instrument uncertainty of measurement. Finally,

div.head: Figure 6d
div.p: shows the map of the hardness values (in rainbow color code) which depends on the (x;y) coordinates and which corresponds to indents showed in Figure 6c.

No meaningful variation of the hardness can be correlated with the microstructure. This result also strongly suggests that hardness is not influenced by the micro-segregations, in line with above-mentionned tensile test results. ductile behavior [29]. Interestingly, the above described mechanical characteristics are similar to that reported for refractory Ti 25 Hf 25 Zr 25 Nb 25 high entropy alloy by Wu et al [12]. Indeed, the author reported that during plastic deformation dislocation tangles are formed and accumulate around grain boundaries and slip bands.

div.head: Microstructure investigations after tensile tests 3.4.1. SEM Analyses
3.4.2: EBSD analyses
div.p: Figure 8 shows typical postmortem investigations by EBSD of the surface of the ascast materials deformed until rupture. Two areas were investigated, one some distance from the necking zone (denoted by A in Fig. 7a) and another area close to the necking zone (marked B in Fig. 7a). Figure 8a which corresponds to the area away from the the necking mainly shows orientation gradients within the grains as well as at grain boundaries. Some deformation bands are visible in the grain marked A at the center of the figure. These bands are however located only in that grain. These observations suggest strong deformation incompatibilities (and heterogeneity) between the grains during the deformation. Figure 8b shows the typical orientation mapping of the area B of the necking surface. The grains are elongated in the tensile direction and their boundaries are extremely distorted. The color gradients within grains and at the vicinity of grain boundaries are more intense, as the lattice distortion level increased. In this line, the grain boundary map of Fig. 8c shows a significant proportion of low angle grain boundaries having misorientation in the range 2-5° (indicated by the green lines in Fig. 7a) that accumulates mostly at the boundary vicinity. In some grains these boundaries form intersecting deformation bands that delineate narrow domains in accordance with SEM observations (Fig. 7b) and TEM studies presented in previous work [25,26]. Further, KAM map shown in Fig. 8d indicate that the level of lattice distortion accompanying dislocation patterning and storage are very high, particularly in the vicinity of the grain boundaries and of the boundaries that delimit lenticular-like structures. With few exceptions, these lenticular structures arise at the grain boundaries and spread more or less far into the interior of the grains. The exact nature has not been determined in the context of the present study. Nevertheless, previous report suggested that they are mixtures of shear bands and deformation twins [7]. But recent investigations by Dirras et al. [34] showed that they are not twins. Nevertheless, dislocation being accumulated and patterned into LAGBs around grains boundaries slip or shear bands are in line with recent report of tensile deformed refractory HEA [12].
These features were at the origin of the large plastic behavior and strengthening of the investigated HEA.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: Elastic and plasticity properties of as-cast TiHfZrTaNb high entropy alloy were investigated by ultrasound measurements and tensile tests up to failure, respectively.
The following results were found:

-Both the Rayleigh surface acoustic wave and the longitudinal sound velocity allowed computation of the Young's modulus E, the bulk modulus B and Poisson ratio Q of about 78.5 GPa, 134.6 GPa and 0.402, respectively, in closer agreement with the Reuss average estimates from DFT calculations [11], potentially suggesting an isostress situation in all grains. The obtained Young modulus is about 30% higher than reported after compression tests (apparent modulus a55 GPa) by Lin et al [35].

-The Pugh ratio G/B as lower as 0. -Local hardness measurements by nano-indentation exhibit similar results for either dendrites or interdendritic zones. This confirms that there is no influence of microsegregation on mechanical behavior.

-Post-mortem EBSD investigations revealed high levels of lattice distortions at the grain boundaries vicinity. These features were at the origin of the strengthening of the investigated HEA and are in line with the available literature reports.

figure.figDesc: and 6 th groups, having compositions of Ti 20 Zr 20 Hf 20 Nb 20 V 20 and Ti 20 Zr 20 Hf 20 Nb 20 Cr 20 , respectively. As in the case of Ti 20 Zr 20 Hf 20 Nb 20 Ta 20 proposed by

The calculated elastic constants C 11 , C12 and C 44 for the Ti 20 Zr 20 Hf 20 Nb 20 Ta 20 single crystalline disordered alloy yielded 160.2 GPa, 124.4 GPa and 62.4 GPa, respectively. The shear modulus G, the bulk modulus B, the Young modulus E and the Poisson ratio Q calculated from the Voigt-Reuss-Hill (VRH) averaging method for the isotropic polycrystalline material yielded 37.9 GPa, 136.3 GPa, 104.1 GPa and 0.373, respectively. Despite worldwide efforts in the field, microstructure and mechanical properties under tensile deformation remain scarce and are still to uncover. In addition as the study concerns with as-solidified microstructure, a question might arise about potential effects of the micro-segregation and non-homogeneous microstructure on the tensile behavior. Based on the work of Couzinié et al [17] who reported inhomogeneity of chemical element along the diameter of as-cast alloy, in the present work, an attempt to answer this question is worked out. Indeed, room temperature tensile behavior, and underlying deformation and failure mechanisms of samples taken along the ingot diameter of ascast Ti 20 Zr 20 Hf 20 Nb 20 Ta 20 HEA are conducted. They are subsequently coupled with nano-indentation measurements to characterize a possible micro-scale change of hardness related to the micro-segregations. Besides, to address the paucity regarding experimental investigation of elastic properties in such an alloy system, tensile test studies were complemented by ultrasound measurements of the longitudinal bulk wave and of the Rayleigh surface acoustic wave by the Brillouin light scattering technique.

figure.head: 14 10 5 cm - 1 ) is shown on Fig. 4 :
figure.figDesc: the expected characteristic features are clearly evidenced, namely a strong Rayleigh peak and a continuum delimited by lower Z R line and upper Z L frequency dip corresponding to the longitudinal threshold [23]. As explained in section 2.4, a computer data fitting of the scattered intensity leads to the determination of the two Brillouin frequencies from which C 11 and C 44 are calculated (C = UV 2 ). Our measurements provide the value of the Rayleigh wave velocity V R = 1640 ± 45 m.s - 1 and the deduced shear wave sound velocity V T = 1679 ± 45 m.s -1 . Previously determined V L value provides a satisfactory agreement between fitted and experimental BLS spectra, near the longitudinal threshold. These velocities yield the following values for the two elastic constants (using the mass density, U = 9929 kg/m 3 , determined by pycnometer): the shear elastic modulus G = C 44 = 28 ± 1.5 GPa and C 11 = 172 ± 6 GPa.

figure.head: Figure 7a shows one
figure.figDesc: Figure 7ashows one half of a sample after rupture. A strong localization of the

208 and a high positive Cauchy pressure (C 12 -C 44 ) = 80 GPa were computed, suggesting a ductile behavior for the investigated material, which was confirmed by tensile tests and SEM examination of the necking and fracture surfaces -Room temperature tensile tests showed only remote micro-segregation effect of the mechanical behavior of the as-cast materials: depending on the specimen location, yield strengths at 0.002 offset in the range a 800 -840 MPa were obtained. The latter are within experimental error.
